captions.text:
In a world where zombie’s have already infected
every facet of pop culture

Get ready for the big-screen adaptation of
the best-selling novel that’s got everything

A film with so many production problems, people
were genuinely surprised when it wasn’t

Meet Gerry Lane, he’s just your average
everyday
“All you do is make pancakes in the morning!"
"Yeah, but I'm really good at it."

Travel the globe with Brad Pitt and the film’s
screenwriters as they stumble from set-piece

to set-piece tied together by the flimsiest
evidence ever.

“There was a memo sent from this installation
that had the word zombie in it. Do you know
"It was an email, not a memo."

Watch Brad Pitt survive an unsurvivable apocalypse
thanks to a constant stream of life-saving

never hitting traffic in the middle of mass
hysteria,

finding an RV with the keys and a loaded gun
inside,

this friendly mugger showing him where to
find medicine,

this friendly Mexican family taking him in
no questions asked,

these fast zombies who slow down as soon as
they’re about to catch him,

this small child head-shotting a zombie on
top of him,

this plane dropping a ladder down to save
him mid-takeoff,

this Israeli soldier killing a zombie about
to eat him,
surviving this spike through his stomach,

and shooting up with a randomly picked virus
that happens to be curable while also serving

So get ready for a by-the-numbers action movie
full of PG-13 violence

and none of these awesome things from the
book:
Man, what a waste of good source material.
Man, all those reshoots must've cost a fortune.

Man, that 
really makes me want a Coke.

comments.author: Lup Synthemesc

comments.text:
This video was dead on for the most part, but how exactly is being a kid 
with asthma a zombie movie cliche? How many zombie apocalypse films have 
used that since Night of the Living Dead? It just seems like Cinema Sins 
and Honest trailers are labeling pretty much everything used more than once 
in movies as a cliche these days. If the goal is to eliminate all cliches 
and never EVER be repetitive in films in any way, shape or form, I'd say 
that's kind of an unrealistic standard. By that logic, I could classify the 
number of extraterrestrial films involving people as the "humans in a movie 
about aliens" cliche. Do you see how silly that is? While films ideally 
should always try to be original and creative, they can still accomplish 
that and have at least some things in common. There's nothing wrong with 
demanding better from what we pay money for, provided it's within reason.﻿

comments.author: Aldo Urquiza

comments.text:
There's a great Max Brooks interview about this movie where they ask him 
what he feels about it and he basically replies "honestly, nothing, I'm not 
pissed or anything because there's nothing FROM my book in the movie for 
them to be disrespecting or ruining, it doesn't even feel like it has any 
connection at all"

What they needed to do was throw out the idea of a movie, this book needed 
to be a well-funded TV miniseries on a good network that can show the gore 
and swearing, something like Showcase or HBO.  Have the series be the 
interviewer going around and doing the interviews, each episode could have 
him start one of the "stories" like the battle of Yonkers or the Satellite 
crew and then fade into the actual episode as the the interview starts as a 
flashback.  They could have easily gotten a good two or three seasons of 
one hour episodes out of that and it would have been long enough to fit 
everything from the beginning to end of the war and would avoid needing to 
have some "jammed in" protagonist no one wanted.  At least that's how I'd 
have pitched it...*sigh* but then no book to zombie story sticks to the 
source material...look at Walking Dead, that comic kicks ass, but the show 
just went way the hell off after the first season and is barely 
recognizable as a walking dead adaptation anymore.﻿
comments.author: ZarathustrasCrown

comments.text:
The closest we can get to a world war z movie is the audiobook. Different 
actors play different characters. The problem is that it's abridged, even 
the complete edition is too. I don't care, mark hamill is a retired vet to 
the zombie war narrating what he did in the army! Kal penn is a Indian 
demolitions expert! Frank darabont is a documentary filmmaker talking about 
laser weapons! Henry Rollins is a mercenary! It's all so good!﻿

comments.author: Allsmiles29 CP

comments.text:
+Allsmiles29 CP The book is amazing. It's done in the style of interviews 
with multiple survivors, but with very few interruptions to their stories. 
It has so many different angles in it, and so many different unique takes 
on how this would happen. There are specific interviews I go back to again 
and again, and they never get boring. Plus, since it's broken into chunks 
like it is, it's the perfect bathroom book!
comments.author: Hannah Schrenk

comments.text:
